Knowledge Point: \phono{-shI} (evidential~--~reportative/quotative) indicates that the speaker has non-perso\-nal-experience evidence for the proposition under the scope of the evidential. \phono{-shI} appears systematically in stories. Often translated as ‘they say.’ \phono{-trI} (evidential~--~conjectural) indicates that the speaker is making a conjecture to the proposition under the scope of the evidential from a set of propositions for which she has either direct or not-direct evidence. Generally translated in Spanish as \spanish{seguro} ‘for sure’, indicating possibility or probability. \phono{-ari} (assertive force) indicates conviction on the part of the speaker. Translated as ‘certainly’ or ‘of course’.\footnote{An anonymous reviewer writes that in other varieties of Quechuan, “\phono{-ari} is interpersonal. It expresses solidarity, affirming what someone else says, thinks or believes to be true.”} \phono{-ik} and \phono{-iki} (evidential modifiers) indicate increasing evidence strength (and increased assertive force or conjectural certainty, in the case of the direct and conjectural modifiers, \phono{-mI} and \phono{-trI}, respectively). Generally translated in Spanish as \spanish{pues} and \spanish{seguro}, respectively. Examples in Table~\ref{Tab30} are fully glossed in the corresponding sections.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: In \SYQ, as in other Quechuan languages, the enclitics can be divided into two classes: (a)~those which position the utterance with regard to others salient in the discourse (restrictive/limitative \phono{-lla}, discontinuative \phono{-ña}, additive \phono{-pis}, topic marking \phono{-qa}, continuative \phono{-Raq}, sequential \phono{-taq}, and interrogative/negative/disjunctive \phono{-chu}); and (b)~those that position the speaker with regard to the utterance (emphatic \phono{-YÁ}, certainty marker \phono{-puni}, and the evidentials \phono{-mi}, \phono{-shi}, and \phono{-tri} along with their modifiers \phono{-ik}, \phono{-iki}, and \phono{-aRi}.). \sectref{ssec:emphatic}--\ref{ssec:emotive} cover all enclitics except the evidentials and their modifiers, in alphabetical order. The evidentials and their modifiers are the subject of \sectref{ssec:evidence}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Realized as \phono{-yá} in all environments~(\ref{Glo6:Ari}--\ref{Glo6:Sirbisatatr}) except following an evidential, in which case both the \phono{I} of the evidential and the \phono{Y} of the emphatic are elided and \phono{Yá} is realized as \phono{á}~(\ref{Glo6:Balikushatr}--\ref{Glo6:Unayqa}).\\
Content 1: \gsrc ¡Ari\textbf{yá}! | \gll ari-yá | \gls yes-EMPH | \glt Yes \textbf{indeed}.
Content 2: \gsrc Sirbisatatr mas mastaqa rantikurun. Sirbisatayá. | \gll sirbisa-ta-tr mas mas-ta-qa ranti-ku-ru-n sirbisa-ta-yá | \gls beer-ACC-EVC more more-ACC-TOP buy-REFL-URGT-3 beer-ACC-EMPH | \glt \spkr~1: “They must have sold a lot more beer.” \spkr~2: “Beer, \textbf{all right}!”
Content 3: \gsrc Balikushatr kara. Payta\textbf{má} rikarani. | \gll baliku-sha-tr ka-ra pay-ta-m-á rika-ra-ni | \gls request.a.service-PRF-EVC be-PST he-ACC-EVD-EMPH see-PST-1 | \glt He must have been requested. I saw him.
Content 4: \gsrc Unayqa Awkichanka inkantakura\textbf{shá} wak altupa yantaman riptiki. | \gll unay-qa Awkichanka inkanta-ku-ra-sh-á wak altu-pa yanta-man ri-pti-ki | \gls before-TOP Awkichanka enchant-REFL-PST-EVR-EMPH DEM.D high-LOC firewood-ALL go-SUBDS-2 | \glt In olden times, Awkichanka, too, bewitched, \textbf{they say}, up hill if you went for firewood.

Knowledge Point: \phono{-chu} indicates absolute~(\ref{Glo6:Iskwilaman}) and disjunctive questions~(\ref{Glo6:Qari}), (\ref{Glo6:Don}), negation~(\ref{Glo6:Chaytri}), and disjunction~(\ref{Glo6:Kandilaryapa}).\footnote{An anonymous reviewer points out that in \ili{Huaylas} Q, negative \phono{-tsu} is distinguished from polar question \phono{-ku}. \ili{Huaylas} is not unique among Quechuan languages in making this distinction.}
Content 1: \gsrc ¿Iskwilaman trurashurqanki\textbf{chu} mamayki? | \gll iskwila-man trura-shu-rqa-nki-chu mama-yki | \gls school-ALL put-2.OBJ-PST-2-Q mother-3 | \glt \textbf{Did} your mother put you in school?
Content 2: \gsrc ¿Qari\textbf{chu} kanki warmi\textbf{chu} kanki? | \gll ¿qari-chu ka-nki warmi-chu ka-nki | \gls man-Q be-2 woman-Q be-2 | \glt Are you a man \textbf{or} a woman?
Content 3: \gsrc ¿Don Juan\textbf{chu} icha alman\textbf{chu} hamuyan? | \gll Don Juan-chu icha alma-n-chu hamu-ya-n | \gls Don Juan-Q or soul-3-Q come-PROG-3 | \glt Is it Don Juan, \textbf{or} is his spirit coming?
Content 4: \gsrc Chaytri \textbf{mana} suyawarqa\textbf{chu}. | \gll chay-tri mana suya-wa-rqa-chu | \gls DEM.D-EVC no wait-1.OBJ-PST-NEG | \glt That’s why she would\textbf{n’t} have waited for me.
Content 5: \gsrc Kandilaryapa\textbf{chu} bintisinkupa\textbf{chu}. | \gll kandilarya-pa-chu binti-sinku-pa-chu | \gls Candelaria-LOC-DISJ twenty-five-LOC-DISJ | \glt \textbf{Either} on Candelaria \textbf{or} on the twenty-fifth.

Knowledge Point: Where it functions to indicate interrogation\index[sub]{interrogation!\phono{-chu}} or negation\index[sub]{negation!\phono{-chu}}, \phono{-chu} attaches to the sentence fragment that is the focus of the interrogation or negation~(\ref{Glo6:Chaypachu}).
Content 1: \gsrc ¿Chaypa\textbf{chu} tumarqanki? | \gll chay-pa-chu tuma-rqa-nki | \gls DEM.D-LOC-Q take-PST-2 | \glt Did you take [pictures] \textbf{there}?

Knowledge Point: Where it functions to indicate disjunction\index[sub]{disjunction} --~in either disjunctive questions or disjunctive statements~-- \phono{-chu} generally attaches to each of the disjuncts~(\ref{Glo6:Mario}).
Content 1: \gsrc Mario\textbf{chu} karqa Julián\textbf{chu} karqa. | \gll Mario-chu ka-rqa Julián-chu ka-rqa | \gls Mario-DISJ be-PST Julián-DISJ be-PST | \glt It was \textbf{either} Mario \textbf{or} Julián.

Knowledge Point: Questions that anticipate a negative answer are indicated by \phono{mana-chu}~(\ref{Glo6:Manachu}).
Content 1: \gsrc ¿\textbf{Manachu} kuska linman? | \gll mana-chu kuska li-n-man | \gls no-Q together go-3-COND | \glt \textbf{Couldn’t} they go together?

Knowledge Point: \phono{mana-chu} may also “soften” questions~(\ref{Glo6:Paysanu}).
Content 1: \gsrc Paysanu, ¿\textbf{manachu} vakata rantiyta munanki? | \gll paysanu mana-chu vaka-ta ranti-y-ta muna-nki | \gls countryman no-Q cow-ACC buy-INF-ACC want-2 | \glt My countryman, \textbf{do you not} want to buy a cow?

Knowledge Point: It may also be used, like \phono{aw} ‘yes’, in the formation of tag questions~(\ref{Glo6:Lliw}).
Content 1: \gsrc Lliw lliwtriki wañukushun, puchukashun entonces, ¿\textbf{manachu}? | \gll lliw lliw-tr-iki wañu-ku-shun puchuka-shun intunsis mana-chu | \gls all all-EVC-IKI die-REFL-1PL.FUT finish.off-1PL.FUT therefore no-Q | \glt We’ll all have to die, to finish off then, \textbf{isn’t that so}?

Knowledge Point: In negative sentences, \phono{-chu} generally co-occurs with \phono{mana} ‘not’~(\ref{Glo6:mana}); \phono{-chu} is also licensed by additive enclitic \phono{-pis}~(\ref{Glo6:Kaspin}), (\ref{Glo6:Manchakushpa}) and \phono{ni} ‘nor’~(\ref{Glo6:Apuraw}), (\ref{Glo6:wayta}).
Content 1: \gsrc Aa, \textbf{mana}yá kan\textbf{chu}. \textbf{Mana}yá bula kan\textbf{chu}. | \gll aa mana-yá ka-n-chu mana-yá bula ka-n-chu | \gls ah no-EMPH be-3-NEG no-EMPH ball be-3-NEG | \glt Ah, there are\textbf{n’t} any. There are\textbf{n’t} any balls.
Content 2: \gsrc Kaspin\textbf{pis} kan\textbf{chu}. | \gll kaspi-n-pis ka-n-chu | \gls stick-3-ADD be-3-NEG | \glt She does\textbf{n’t} have a stick.
Content 3: \gsrc Manchakushpa tuta\textbf{s} puñu:\textbf{chu}. | \gll mancha-ku-shpa tuta-s puñu-:-chu | \gls scare-REFL-SUBIS night-ADD sleep-1-NEG | \glt Being scared, I \textbf{don’t} sleep at night.
Content 4: \gsrc Apuraw wañururqariki. \textbf{Ni} apanña\textbf{chu}. | \gll apuraw wañu-ru-rqa-r-iki ni apa-n-ña-chu | \gls quick die-URGT-PST-R-IKI nor bring-3-DISC-NEG | \glt He died quickly. They \textbf{didn’t even} bring him [to the hospital].
Content 5: \gsrc \textbf{Manam} wayta\textbf{chu} \textbf{ni} pishqu\textbf{chu}. | \gll mana-m wayta-chu ni pishqu-chu | \gls no-EVD flower-NEG nor bird-NEG | \glt \textbf{Neither} a flower \textbf{nor} a bird.

Knowledge Point: In prohibitions, \phono{-chu} co-occurs with \phono{ama} ‘don’t’~(\ref{Glo6:wawqi}).
Content 1: \gsrc “¡\textbf{Ama} wawqi:taqa wañuchiy\textbf{chu}!” niptinshi wañurachin paywantapis. | \gll ama wawqi-:-ta-qa wañu-chi-y-chu ni-pti-n-shi wañu-ra-chi-n pay-wan-ta-pis | \gls PROH brother-1-ACC-TOP die-CAUS-IMP-NEG say-SUBDS-3-EVR die-URGT-CAUS-3 he-INSTR-ACC-ADD | \glt When he said, “\textbf{Don’t} kill my brother!” they killed him with him, too.

Knowledge Point: \phono{-chu} does not appear in subordinate clauses, where negation is indicated with a negative particle alone~(\ref{Glo6:qali}), (\ref{Glo6:qatrachakunanpaq}).\footnote{An anonymous reviewer points out that elsewhere in Quechua, the correlates of negative \phono{-chu} typically can appear in subordinate clauses. There are no naturally-occurring examples of this in the Yauyos corpus.}
Content 1: \gsrc \textbf{Mana} qali kaptinqa ñuqanchikpis taqllakta hapishpa qaluwanchik. | \gll mana qali ka-pti-n-qa ñuqanchik-pis taqlla-kta hapi-shpa qaluwa-nchik | \gls no man be-SUBDS-3-TOP we-ADD plow-ACC grab-SUBIS turn.earth-1PL | \glt When there are \textbf{no} \textbf{men}, we grab the plow and turn the earth.
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Mana} qatrachakunanpaq mandilchanta watachakun. | \gll mana qatra-cha-ku-na-n-paq mandil-cha-n-ta wata-cha-ku-n | \gls no dirty-FACT-REFL-NMLZ-3-PURP apron-DIM-3-ACC tie-DIM-REFL-3 | \glt She’s tying on an apron \textbf{so} she \textbf{doesn’t} get dirty.

Knowledge Point: In negative sentences, \phono{-chu} never occurs on the same segment as does an evidential enclitic~(\ref{Glo6:lluqsirqanki}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Finally, interrogative \phono{-chu} is further restricted in that it does not appear in questions using interrogative pronouns~(\ref{Glo6:hamurqa}).\footnote{\phono{¿*Pi-taq} \phono{hamu-n-chu?} \phono{¿*Pi-taq-chu} \phono{hamu-n?} ‘Who is coming?’}
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: \phono{-lla} indicates exclusivity or limitation in number\index[sub]{restrictive}: the individual~(\ref{Glo6:Iskwilapam}--\ref{Glo6:Kichwa}) or event/event type~(\ref{Glo6:Fwirti}), (\ref{Glo6:lliwtam}) remains limited to itself and is accompanied by no other.
Content 1: \gsrc Iskwilapam niytu:kunaqa wawa:kunaqa rinmi ñuqa\textbf{lla}m ka: analfabitu. | \gll iskwila-pa-m niytu-:-kuna-qa wawa-:-kuna-qa ri-n-mi ñuqa-lla-m ka-: analfabitu | \gls school-LOC-EVD nephew-1-PL-TOP baby-1-PL-TOP go-3-EVD I-RSTR-EVD be-1 illiterate | \glt My grandchildren are in school. My children went. I’m the \textbf{only} illiterate one.
Content 2: \gsrc Kichwa\textbf{lla}ktam limakuya: kaytrawlaq manam kastillanukta lima:chu. | \gll kichwa-lla-kta-m lima-ku-ya-: kay-traw-laq mana-m kastillanu-kta lima-:-chu | \gls Quechua-RSTR-ACC-EVD speak-REFL-PROG-1 DEM.P-LOC-CONT no-EVD Spanish-ACC speak-1-NEG | \glt I’m talking \textbf{just} Quechua. Here, still, we don’t speak Spanish.
Content 3: \gsrc Fwirti kashpa\textbf{lla}má linchik pustaman. | \gll fwirti ka-shpa-lla-m-á li-nchik pusta-man | \gls strong be-SUBIS-RSTR-EVD-EMPH go-1PL clinic-ALL | \glt \textbf{Only} if it’s bad will we go to the health clinic.
Content 4: \gsrc Lliw lliwtam rantishpa\textbf{lla}ñam kanan kamatapis chay polarkunatapis. | \gll lliw lliw-ta-m ranti-shpa-lla-ña-m kanan kama-ta-pis chay polar-kuna-ta-pis | \gls all all-ACC-EVD buy-SUBIS-RSTR-DISC-EVD now blanket-ACC-ADD DEM.D fleece-PL-ACC-ADD | \glt Now \textbf{just} buying everything -- blankets, [polyester] fleece.

Knowledge Point: \phono{-lla} can generally be translated as ‘just’~(\ref{Glo6:Chayna}), (\ref{Glo6:Sirka}) or ‘only’~(\ref{Glo6:Chay}); it sometimes has an ‘exactly’ interpretation~(\ref{Glo6:Iskinanpi}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc Sirka\textbf{lla}tam riya: manam karutachu. | \gll sirka-lla-ta-m ri-ya-: mana-m karu-ta-chu | \gls close-RSTR-ACC-EVD go-PROG-1 no-EVD far-ACC-NEG | \glt I \textbf{just} go close; I don’t go far.
Content 3: \gsrc Chay\textbf{lla}tam yatrani. Masta yatranichu. | \gll chay-lla-ta-m yatra-ni mas-ta yatra-ni-chu | \gls DEM.D-LIM-ACC-EVD know-1 more-ACC know-1-NEG | \glt I \textbf{only} know that. I don’t know more.
Content 4: \gsrc Iskinanpi sikya tuna\textbf{lla}npi wallpay watrakunraq. | \gll iskina-n-pi sikya tuna-lla-n-pi wallpa-y watra-ku-n-raq | \gls corner-3-LOC aqueduct corner-RSTR-3-LOC chicken-1 give.birth-REFL-3-CONT | \glt My hen lays eggs in the corner, \textbf{right} in the corner of the canal.

Knowledge Point: It is very, very widely employed~(\ref{Glo6:abaskuna}--\ref{Glo6:Chaytam}).
Content 1: \gsrc Lliwta abaskuna albirhakuna ayvis\textbf{lla} rantikuni apani llaqtatam. | \gll lliw-ta abas-kuna albirha-kuna ayvis-lla ranti-ku-ni apa-ni llaqta-ta-m | \gls all-ACC broad.beans-PL peas-PL sometimes-RSTR buy-REFL-1 bring-1 town-ACC-EVD | \glt Everything -- broad beans, peas -- \textbf{once in while} I sell stuff -- I bring it into town.
Content 2: \gsrc Chaytam aysashpa\textbf{lla} pasachiwaq. | \gll chay-ta-m aysa-shpa-lla pasa-chi-wa-q | \gls DEM.D-ACC-EVD pull-SUBIS-RSTR pass-CAUS-1.OBJ-AG | \glt They had me cross the river pulling [me by the hand].

Knowledge Point: Discontinuitive. \phono{-ña}\index[sub]{discontinuitive} indicates transition --~change of state or quality. In affirmative statements, it can generally be translated as ‘already’~(\ref{Glo6:Kundinadaw}--\ref{Glo6:Paqwayanchik}); in negative statements, as ‘no more’ or ‘no longer’~(\ref{Glo6:Unaytrik}), (\ref{Glo6:Manana}); and in questions, as ‘yet’~(\ref{Glo6:Pasarun}), (\ref{Glo6:Rimaya}).
Content 1: \gsrc Kundinadaw\textbf{ña}m wakqa kayan. | \gll kundinadaw-ña-m wak-qa ka-ya-n | \gls condemned-DISC-EVD DEM.D-TOP be-PROG-3 | \glt That one is \textbf{already} condemned.
Content 2: \gsrc Paqwayanchik\textbf{ña}m talpuyta, ¿aw? Papaktapis talpulalu:\textbf{ña}m, kanan halakta, ¿aw? | \gll paqwa-ya-nchik-ña-m talpu-y-ta aw papa-kta-pis talpu-la-lu-:-ña-m kanan hala-kta aw | \gls finish-PROG-1PL-DISC-EVD plant-INF-ACC yes potato-ACC-ADD plant-UNINT-URGT-1-DISC-EVD now corn-ACC yes | \glt We’re finishing the planting \textbf{already}, no? We’ve \textbf{already} planted the potatoes, now the corn, no?
Content 3: \gsrc Unaytrik. Kananqa kan\textbf{ña}chu imapis. | \gll unay-tri-k kanan-qa ka-n-ña-chu ima-pis | \gls before-EVC-IK now-TOP be-3-DISC-NEG what-ADD | \glt That would be a long time ago. Now there isn’t anything \textbf{any more}.
Content 4: \gsrc \textbf{Manaña} ni santu ni imapis. | \gll mana-ña ni santu ni ima-pis | \gls no-DISC nor saint nor what-ADD | \glt There are \textbf{no longer} saints or anything.
Content 5: \gsrc ¿Pasarun\textbf{ñachu}? Tapushun. | \gll pasa-ru-n-ña-chu tapu-shun | \gls pass-URGT-3-DISC-Q ask-1PL.FUT | \glt Did she go by \textbf{yet}? Let’s ask.
Content 6: \gsrc ¿Rimaya\textbf{nña}\textbf{chu} kanan wakpi? | \gll rima-ya-n-ña-chu kanan wak-pi | \gls talk-PROG-3-DISC-Q now DEM.D-LOC | \glt Are they talking \textbf{yet} there now?

Knowledge Point: It can appear freely but never unaccompanied, redundantly, by \phono{ña}~(\ref{Glo6:tukuchkani}), (\ref{Glo6:riqsiyan}).
Content 1: \gsrc “¡\textbf{Ñam} tukuchkani\textbf{ña}!” ¡Puk! ¡Puk! ¡Puk! sikisapa sapu. | \gll ña-m tuku-chka-ni-ña puk puk puk siki-sapa sapu | \gls DISC-EVD finish-DUR-1-DISC puk puk puk behind-MULT.POSS frog | \glt “I’m \textbf{already} finishing up!” Puk! Puk! Puk! said the frog with the behind bigger than usual.
Content 2: \gsrc \textbf{Ñam} riqsiyan\textbf{ña} hukya yaykun. | \gll ña-m riqsi-ya-n-ña huk-ya yayku-n | \gls DISC-EVD know-PROG-3-DISC one-EMPH enter-3 | \glt They’re getting to know it \textbf{already} and another comes in.

Knowledge Point: \phono{-pis}\index[sub]{inclusion} indicates the inclusion of an item or event into a series of similar items or events. Translated as ‘and’, ‘too’, ‘also’, and ‘even’~(\ref{Glo6:Turnuchawan}--\ref{Glo6:Mamanwa}) or, when negated, ‘neither’ or ‘not even’~(\ref{Glo6:Imapaqtaq}--\ref{Glo6:Pata}).
Content 1: \gsrc Turnuchawan ñuqakunaqa trabaha: walmi\textbf{pis} qali\textbf{pis}. | \gll turnu-cha-wan ñuqa-kuna-qa trabaha-: walmi-pis qali-pis | \gls turn-DIM-INSTR I-PL-TOP work-1 woman-ADD man-ADD | \glt We work in turns, the women \textbf{and} the men.
Content 2: \gsrc Maman wañukuptin\textbf{pis} manam waqanchu. | \gll mama-n wañu-ku-pti-n-pis mana-m waqa-n-chu | \gls mother-3 die-REFL-SUBDS-3-ADD no-EVD cry-3-NEG | \glt \textbf{Even} when his mother died, he didn’t cry.
Content 3: \gsrc “¿Imapaqtaq ñuqa waqashaq?” nin. “Warmiypaq\textbf{pis} waqarqani\textbf{chu}.” | \gll ima-paq-taq ñuqa waqa-shaq nin warmi-y-paq-pis waqa-rqa-ni-chu | \gls what-PURP-SEQ I cry-1.FUT say-3 woman-1-BEN-ADD cry-PST-1-NEG | \glt “Why am I going to cry?” he said. “I did\textbf{n’t} cry for my wife, \textbf{either}.”
Content 4: \gsrc Pata saqayta\textbf{pis} atipan\textbf{chu}. | \gll pata saqa-y-ta-pis atipa-n-chu | \gls terrace go.up-INF-ACC-ADD be.able-3-NEG | \glt They ca\textbf{n’t} \textbf{even} go up one terrace.

Knowledge Point: \phono{-pis} may --~or, even, may generally~-- imply contrast with some preceding element. Where it scopes over subordinate clauses, it can often be translated ‘although’ or ‘even’~(\ref{Glo6:Uratam}), (\ref{Glo6:Hinaptin}).
Content 1: \gsrc Uratam muna\textbf{shpapis}. | \gll ura-ta-m muna-shpa-pis | \gls hour-ACC-EVD want-SUBIS-ADD | \glt \textbf{Although} I want to know the time.
Content 2: \gsrc Hinaptin wasipiña rumiwan takaptin\textbf{pis} uyan\textbf{chu}. | \gll hinaptin wasi-pi-ña rumi-wan taka-pti-n-pis uya-n-chu | \gls then house-LOC-DISC stone-INSTR hit-SUBDS-3-ADD be.able-3-NEG | \glt Later, at home, \textbf{even when} they hit it with a rock, it couldn’t.

Knowledge Point: Attaching to interrogative-indefinite stems, it forms indefinites and, with \phono{mana}, negative indefinites~(\ref{Glo6:Chaynam}--\ref{Glo6:chambyakuqpaq}).
Content 1: \gsrc Chaynam \textbf{imallatapis} wasiman apamun. | \gll chayna-m ima-lla-ta-pis wasi-man apa-mu-n | \gls thus-EVD what-RSTR-ACC-ADD house-ALL bring-CISL-3 | \glt That way he brings a little \textbf{something} to his house.
Content 2: \gsrc Alli chambyakuqpaq \textbf{manam imapis} faltanmanchu. | \gll alli chambya-ku-q-paq mana ima-pis falta-n-man-chu | \gls good work-REFL-AG-BEN no what-ADD be.missing-3-COND-NEG | \glt \textbf{Nothing} can be lacking for a good worker.

Knowledge Point: It is in free variation with \phono{-pas}, and, after a vowel, with \phono{-s}~(\ref{Glo6:Diskansakamuy}--\ref{Glo6:harquruwara}), the latter particularly common in the \ACH{} dialect.
Content 1: \gsrc “¡Diskansakamuy wasikipa!” niwan kikin\textbf{pas} diskansuman ripun. | \gll diskansa-ka-mu-y wasi-ki-pa ni-wa-n kiki-n-pas diskansu-man ripu-n | \gls rest-REFL-CISL-IMP house-2-LOC say-1.OBJ-3 self-3-ADD rest-ALL go-3 | \glt “Go rest in your house,” he said to me and he, himself, \textbf{too}, went to rest.
Content 2: \gsrc Ñuqata\textbf{s} harquruwara Kashapataman riranim. | \gll ñuqa-ta-s harqu-ru-wa-ra Kashapata-man ri-ra-ni-m | \gls I-ACC-ADD toss.out-URGT-1.OBJ-PST Kashapata-ALL go-PST-1-EVD | \glt They threw me out, \textbf{too}, and I went to Kashapata.

Knowledge Point: \phono{-qa}\index[sub]{topic marker} indicates the topic of a clause~(\ref{Glo6:sultiram}--\ref{Glo6:Difindiwanchik}), including in those cases where it attaches to subordinate clauses~(\ref{Glo6:pasiyuman}), (\ref{Glo6:Qipiruptinqa}).
Content 1: \gsrc Madri sultiram kaya: ñuqalla\textbf{qa}. | \gll madri sultira-m ka-ya-: ñuqa-lla-qa | \gls mother alone-EVD be-PROG-1 I-RSTR-TOP | \glt \textbf{I}’m a single mother.
Content 2: \gsrc Difindiwanchik malichukunapaq\textbf{qa}. | \gll difindi-wa-nchik malichu-kuna-paq-qa | \gls defend-1.OBJ-1PL curse-PL-ABL-TOP | \glt It protects us against \textbf{curses}.
Content 3: \gsrc Lluqsila pasiyuman yaykushpa\textbf{qa} manaña puydila\uo{}chu piru. | \gll lluqsi-la pasiyu-man yayku-shpa-qa mana-ña puydi-la-chu piru | \gls go.out-PST walk-ALL enter-SUBIS-TOP no-DISC be.able-PST-NEG but | \glt They went out for a walk but \textbf{when they went in}, they couldn’t.
Content 4: \gsrc Qipiruptinqa~\dots{} chay kundur\textbf{qa} qipiptin huk turuta pagaykun. | \gll qipi-ru-pti-n-qa chay kundur-qa qipi-pti-n huk turu-ta paga-yku-n | \gls carry-URGT-SUBDS-3-TOP DEM.D condor-TOP carry-SUBDS-3 one bull-ACC pay-EXCEP-3 | \glt \textbf{When he carried her}, after the condor carried her, she payed him a bull.

Knowledge Point: \phono{-Raq}\index[sub]{continuitive} --~realized in \CH{} as \phono{-laq}~(\ref{Glo6:Kichwallaktam}) and in all other dialects as \phono{-raq}~-- indicates continuity of action, state or quality.
Content 1: \gsrc Kichwallaktam limakuya: kaytraw\textbf{laq} manam kastillanukta lima:chu. | \gll kichwa-lla-kta-m lima-ku-ya-: kay-traw-laq mana-m kastillanu-kta lima-:-chu | \gls Quechua-RSTR-ACC-EVD talk-REFL-PROG-1 DEM.P-LOC-CONT no-EVD Spanish-ACC talk-1-NEG | \glt I’m just talking Quechua. Here, \textbf{still}, we don’t speak Spanish.

Knowledge Point: It can generally be translated ‘still’~(\ref{Glo6:Qamqa}--\ref{Glo6:Kamanpi}) or, negated, ‘yet’~(\ref{Glo6:Runtuwanmi}), (\ref{Glo6:mayqinniypis}).
Content 1: \gsrc Qamqa flaku\textbf{raq}mi. Hawlapam qamtaqa wirayachisayki. | \gll qam-qa flaku-raq-mi hawla-pa-m qam-ta-qa wira-ya-chi-sayki | \gls you-TOP skinny-CONT-EVD cage-LOC-EVD you-ACC-TOP fat-INCH-CAUS-1>2.FUT | \glt You’re \textbf{still} skinny. I’m going to fatten you up in a cage.
Content 2: \gsrc Kamanpi puñukuyaptin\textbf{raq} tarirun. | \gll kama-n-pi puñu-ku-ya-pti-n-raq tari-ru-n | \gls bed-3-LOC sleep-REFL-PROG-SUBDS-3-CONT find-URGT-3 | \glt He found him when he was sleeping \textbf{still} in his bed.
Content 3: \gsrc Runtuwanmi qaquyanmi chaypa \textbf{mana}\textbf{raq}mi shakashwan. | \gll runtu-wan-mi qaqu-ya-n-mi chay-pa mana-raq-mi shakash-wan | \gls egg-INSTR-EVD massage-PROG-3-EVD DEM.D-LOC no-CONT-EVD guinea.pig-INSTR | \glt He’s massaging with an egg -- \textbf{not yet} with the guinea pig.
Content 4: \gsrc \textbf{Mana}m mayqinniypis wañuni\textbf{raq}chu. | \gll mana-m mayqin-ni-y-pis wañu-ni-raq-chu | \gls no-EVD which-EUPH-1-ADD die-1-CONT-NEG | \glt \textbf{None} of us has died yet.

Knowledge Point: Marking rhetorical questions, it can indicate a kind of despair~(\ref{Glo6:Yawarnintachu}), (\ref{Glo6:gringukunaqa}).
Content 1: \gsrc ¿Yawarnintachu? ¿Imata\textbf{raq} hurqura chay dimunyukuna? | \gll yawar-ni-n-ta-chu ima-ta-raq hurqu-ra chay dimunyu-kuna | \gls blood-EUPH-3-ACC-Q what-ACC-CONT take.out-PST DEM.D Devil-PL | \glt His blood? \textbf{What in the world} did the devil suck out of him?
Content 2: \gsrc Chay gringukunaqa altukunatash rin. ¿Imayna\textbf{raq} chay runata wañuchin? | \gll chay gringu-kuna-qa altu-kuna-ta-sh ri-n imayna-raq chay runa-ta wañu-chi-n | \gls DEM.D gringo-PL-TOP high-PL-ACC-EVR go-3 how-CONT DEM.D PERSON-ACC die-CAUS-3 | \glt The gringos go to the heights, they say. \textbf{How on earth} could they kill those people?

Knowledge Point: With subordinate clauses, it may indicate a prerequisite or a necessary condition for the event to take place, translating in English as ‘first’ or ‘not until’~(\ref{Glo6:ruwashpa}).
Content 1: \gsrc Kisuta ruwashpa\textbf{raq} trayamuyan. | \gll kisu-ta ruwa-shpa-raq traya-mu-ya-n | \gls cheese-ACC make-SUBIS-CONT arrive-CISL-PROG-3 | \glt \textbf{Once} she makes the cheese, she’s coming.

Knowledge Point: \phono{Chay-raq} indicates an imminent future, translating in Andean Spanish \spanish{recién}~(\ref{Glo6:tapayan}). Employed as a coordinator, it implies a contrast between the coordinated elements (see~\sectref{sec:coord}).
Content 1: \gsrc Chay\textbf{raq}mi tapayan. Qallaykuyani chay\textbf{raq}. | \gll chay-raq-mi tapa-ya-n qalla-yku-ya-ni chay-raq | \gls DEM.D-CONT-EVD cover-PROG-3 begin-EXCEP-PROG-1 DEM.D-CONT | \glt He’s \textbf{just now going to} cap it. I’m \textbf{just now} going to start.

Knowledge Point: \phono{-taq}\index[sub]{sequential} indicates the sequence of events~(\ref{Glo6:Tardiqa}).
Content 1: \gsrc Tardiqa yapa listu suyan; yapa\textbf{taq}shi trayarun. | \gll tardi-qa yapa listu suya-n yapa-taq-shi traya-ru-n | \gls afternoon-TOP again ready wait-3 again-SEQ-EVR arrive-URGT-3 | \glt In the afternoon, \textbf{again}, ready, he waits. \textbf{Then, again}, [the zombie] arrived.

Knowledge Point: Adelaar~(p.c.)\index[aut]{Adelaar, Willem F. H.} points out that in \ili{Ayacucho} Quechua \phono{-ña-taq} is a fixed combination. It appears that may be the case here too~(\ref{Glo6:pikarushpa}--\ref{Glo6:makiywan}). In these examples \phono{-taq} seems to continue to indicate a sequence of events.
Content 1: \gsrc Lliwta pikarushpa, kaymanñataq quturini trurani wakmanña\textbf{taq}. | \gll lliw-ta pika-ru-shpa kay-man-ña-taq qutu-ri-ni trura-ni wak-man-ña-taq | \gls all-ACC pick-URGT-SUBDS DEM.D-ALL-DISC-SEQ gather-INCEP-1 put-1 DEM.P-ALL-DISC-SEQ | \glt When I have all these sorted, \textbf{then} I gather everything here and \textbf{then} store it there.
Content 2: \gsrc Ñuqapa makiywan aytrichiyanmi. Kanan trakillaña\textbf{taq}. Huknin makiwanña\textbf{taq} kananmi. | \gll ñuqa-pa maki-y-wan aytri-chi-ya-n-mi kanan traki-lla-ña-taq huk-ni-n maki-wan-ña-taq kanan-mi | \gls I-GEN hand-1-INSTR stir-CAUS-PROG-3-EVD now foot-RSTR-DISC-SEQ one-EUPH-3 hand-INSTR-DISC-SEQ now-EVD | \glt He’s stirring it with my hand. Now, the foot. Now with the other hand.

Knowledge Point: In a question introduced by an interrogative (\phono{pi-}, \phono{ima-}~\dots) \phono{-taq} attaches to the interrogative in case it is the only word in the phrase or, in case the phrase includes two or more words, to the final word in the phrase (\ref{Glo6:Ishpaykuruwan}--\ref{Glo6:Imanashaq}).
Content 1: \gsrc ¡Ishpaykuruwan! ¿Imapaq\textbf{taq} ishpan? | \gll ishpa-yku-ru-wa-n ima-paq-taq ishpa-n | \gls urinate-EXCEP-URGT-1.OBJ-3 what-PURP-SEQ urinate-3 | \glt It urinated on me! \textbf{Why} does it urinate?
Content 2: \gsrc ¿Imanashaq\textbf{taq}? Diosllatañatriki. | \gll ima-na-shaq-taq Dios-lla-ta-ña-tr-iki | \gls what-VRBZ-1.FUT-SEQ God-RSTR-ACC-DISC-EVC-IKI | \glt \textbf{What am I going to do}? It’s for God already.

Knowledge Point: In this capacity, \phono{-taq} may be the most transparent of the enclitics attaching to \phono{q}-phrases. In a clause with a conditional or in a subordinate clause, \phono{-taq} can indicate a warning~(\ref{Glo6:Kurasunniyman}).
Content 1: \gsrc Kurasunniyman shakashta trurayan. Ñuqa niyani “¡Kaniruwaptinña\textbf{taq}!” | \gll kurasun-ni-y-man shakash-ta trura-ya-n ñuqa ni-ya-ni kani-ru-wa-pti-n-ña-taq | \gls heart-EUPH-1-ALL guinea.pig-ACC put-PROG-3 I say-PROG-1 bite-URGT-1.OBJ-SUBDS-3-DISC-SEQ | \glt He’s putting the guinea pig over my heart. I’m saying, “\textbf{Be careful} it doesn’t bite me!”

Knowledge Point: \phono{-taq} also functions as a conjunction~(\ref{Glo6:puchkawan}) (see~\sectref{sec:coord}).
Content 1: \gsrc Warmiña\textbf{taq} puchkawan qariña\textbf{taq} tihiduwan. | \gll warmi-ña-taq puchka-wan qari-ña-taq tihidu-wan | \gls women-DISC-SEQ spinning-INSTR man-DISC-SEQ weaving-INSTR | \glt Women with spinning \textbf{and} men with weaving.

Knowledge Point: Evidentials\index[sub]{evidentials} indicate the type of the speaker’s source of information. \SYQ, like most\footnote{Note, though, that \ili{Huallaga} Q counts four evidentials, (\phono{-mi}, \phono{-shi}, \phono{-chi}, snd \phono{-chaq}) (Weber 1989:76). South \ili{Conchucos} Q counts six, (\phono{-mi}, \phono{-shi}, \phono{-chi}, \phono{-cha:}, and \phono{-cher}); \ili{Sihuas}, too, counts six (Hintz and Hintz 2014).} other Quechuan languages, counts three evidential suffixes: direct \phono{-mi}~(\ref{Glo6:Taytacha}--\ref{Glo6:puntraw}), reportative \phono{-shi}~(\ref{Glo6:Radyukunapa}--\ref{Glo6:Qarinta}), and conjectural \phono{-tri}~(\ref{Glo6:trayarachiptiki}--\ref{Glo6:Wasiy}) (\ie~the speaker has her own evidence for P (generally visual); the speaker learned P from someone else; or the speaker infers P based on some other evidence). Following a short vowel, these are realized as \phono{-m}, \phono{sh}, and \phono{-tr}, respectively~(\ref{Glo6:puntraw}), (\ref{Glo6:Qarinta}), (\ref{Glo6:Wasiy}).
Content 1: \gsrc Taytacha José irransakurqa chaypa\textbf{m}. | \gll tayta-cha José irransa-ku-rqa chay-pa-m | \gls father-DIM José herranza-REFL-PST DEM.D-LOC-EVD | \glt My grandfather José held herranzas \textbf{there}.
Content 2: \gsrc Qayna puntraw qanin puntrawlla\textbf{m} trayamura:. | \gll qayna puntraw qanin puntraw-lla-m traya-mu-ra-: | \gls previous day day.before.yesterday day-RSTR-EVD arrive-CISL-PST-1 | \glt I arrived yesterday, \textbf{just the day} before yesterday.
Content 3: \gsrc Radyukunapa rimayta rimayan. Lluqsiyamun\textbf{shi} tirrurista. Tirrurista rikariyamun\textbf{shi}. | \gll radyu-kuna-pa rima-y-ta rima-ya-n lluqsi-ya-mu-n-shi tirrurista tirrurista rikari-ya-mu-n-shi | \gls radio-PL-LOC talk-INF-ACC talk-PROG-3 go.out-PROG-CISL-3-EVR terrorist terrorist appear-PROG-CISL-3-EVR | \glt On the radio they talk for the sake of talking. Terrorists \textbf{are coming out, they say}. Terrorists \textbf{are appearing, they say}.
Content 4: \gsrc Qarinta\textbf{sh} wañurachin mashanta\textbf{sh} wañurachin. | \gll qari-n-ta-sh wañu-ra-chi-n masha-n-ta-sh wañu-ra-chi-n | \gls man-3-ACC-EVR die-URGT-CAUS-3 son.in.law-3-ACC-EVR die-URGT-CAUS-3 | \glt She killed her \textbf{husband, they say}; she killed her \textbf{son-in-law, they say}.
Content 5: \gsrc Qiñwalman trayarachiptiki wañukunman\textbf{tri}. | \gll qiñwal-man traya-ra-chi-pti-ki wañu-ku-n-man-tri | \gls quingual.grove-ALL arrive-URGT-CAUS-SUBDS-2 die-REFL-3-COND-EVC | \glt If you make her go all the way to the quingual grove, she might die.
Content 6: \gsrc Wasiy rahasa kayan. Saqaykurunqa\textbf{tr}. | \gll wasi-y raha-sa ka-ya-n saqa-yku-ru-nqa-tr | \gls house-1 crack-PRF be-PROG-3 go.down-EXCEP-URGT-3.FUT-EVC | \glt My house is cracked. \textbf{It’s going to fall down}.
Content 7: \gsrc Qayna puntraw qanin puntrawlla\textbf{m} trayamura:. | \gll qayna puntraw qanin puntraw-lla-m traya-mu-ra-: | \gls previous day day.before.yesterday day-RSTR-EVD arrive-CISL-PST-1 | \glt I arrived yesterday, \textbf{just the day} before yesterday.
Content 8: \gsrc Qarinta\textbf{sh} wañurachin mashanta\textbf{sh} wañurachin. | \gll qari-n-ta-sh wañu-ra-chi-n masha-n-ta-sh wañu-ra-chi-n | \gls man-3-ACC-EVR die-URGT-CAUS-3 son.in.law-3-ACC-EVR die-URGT-CAUS-3 | \glt She killed her \textbf{husband, they say}; she killed her \textbf{son-in-law, they say}.
Content 9: \gsrc Wasiy rahasa kayan. Saqaykurunqa\textbf{tr}. | \gll wasi-y raha-sa ka-ya-n saqa-yku-ru-nqa-tr | \gls house-1 crack-PRF be-PROG-3 go.down-EXCEP-URGT-3.FUT-EVC | \glt My house is cracked. \textbf{It’s going to fall down}.

Knowledge Point: In addition to indicating the speaker’s information type, evidentials also function to indicate focus or comment and to complete copular predicates (for further discussion and examples, see \sectref{sec:emphasis} and~\ref{sec:equative} on emphasis and equatives).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Evidentials are subject to the following distributional restrictions. They never attach to the topic or subject; these are, rather, marked with \phono{-qa}. In content questions, the evidential attaches to the question word or to the last word of the questioned phrase~(\ref{Glo6:chay}) (see~\sectref{sec:interr} on interrogation).
Content 1: \gsrc ¿May\textbf{mi} chay warmi? | \gll may-mi chay warmi | \gls where-EVD DEM.D woman | \glt \textbf{Where} is that woman?

Knowledge Point: Evidentials do not appear in commands or injunctions~(\ref{Glo6:Ruwaruchun}); finally, only one evidential may occur per clause~(\ref{Glo6:Vakay}).
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gsrc ¡Vakay wira wira\textbf{m}, matraypi puñushpa, allin pastuta mikushpa\textbf{m}. | \gll vaka-y wira wira-m matray-pi puñu-shpa allin pastu-ta miku-shpa-m | \gls cow-1 fat fat-EVD cave-LOC sleep-SUBIS good pasture.grass-ACC eat-REFL-EVD | \glt My cow is really fat, sleeping in a cave and eating good pasture grass.

Knowledge Point: All three evidentials are interpreted as assertions. The first, \phono{-mI}, is generally left untranslated in Spanish; the second, \phono{-shI}, is often rendered \phono{dice} ‘they say’; the third is reflected in a change in verb tense or mode (see~\sectref{ssec:conjectural}). The difference between the three is a matter, first, of whether or not evidence is from personal experience, and, second, whether that evidence supports the proposition, \phono{p}, immediately under the scope of the evidential or another set of propositions, \phono{P’}, that are evidence for \phono{p}, as represented in Table \ref{Tab31}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: So, employing \phono{-mI}(\phono{p}), the speaker asserts predicate \phono{p} and represents that she has personal-experience evidence for \phono{p}; employing \phono{-shI}(\phono{p}), the speaker asserts \phono{p} and refers the hearer to another source for evidence for \phono{p}; and employing \phono{-trI}(\phono{p}), the speaker asserts \phono{p} and represents that \phono{p} is a conjecture from \phono{P’}, propositions for which she has either \phono{-mI}-type or \phono{-shI}-type evidence or both. That is, although \SYQ{} counts three evidential suffixes, it counts only two evidence types, direct and reportative; these two are jointly exhaustive. \sectref{ssec:direct}--\ref{ssec:conjectural} cover \phono{-mI}, \phono{-shI}, and \phono{trI}, in turn. \sectref{ssec:evidmodifi} covers the evidential modifiers, \phono{-ari} and \phono{-ik/iki}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: \phono{-mI}\index[sub]{evidentials!direct} indicates that the speaker speaks from direct experience. Unlike \phono{-shI} and \phono{-trI}, it is generally left untranslated. Note that in the examples below, with the exception of~(\ref{Glo6:Vakaqa}), the speaker’s knowledge is not the product of visual experience.
Content 1: \gsrc Vakaqa kaypa waqrayuq\textbf{mi}ki kayan. | \gll vaka-qa kay-pa waqra-yuq-m-iki ka-ya-n | \gls cow-TOP DEM.P-LOC horn-POSS-EVD-IKI be-PROG-3 | \glt The cows here \textbf{have horns}.

Knowledge Point: \phono{-shI}\index[sub]{evidentials!reportative} indicates that the speaker’s evidence does not come from personal experience~(\ref{Glo6:Awkichanka}--\ref{Glo6:Lata}).
Content 1: \gsrc Awkichanka urqupaqa inkantu\textbf{sh} -- karru\textbf{sh} chinkarurqa qutrapa. | \gll Awkichanka urqu-pa-qa inkantu-sh karru-sh chinka-ru-rqa qutra-pa | \gls Awkichanka hill-LOC-TOP spirit-EVR car-EVR lose-URGT-PST lake-LOC | \glt In the hill Okichanka, there is \textbf{a spirit, they say} -- a car was lost in a reservoir.
Content 2: \gsrc Lata-wan yanu-shpa-taq-\textbf{shi} runa-ta-pis miku-ru-ra. | \gll lata-wan yanu-shpa-taq-shi runa-ta-pis miku-ru-ra | \gls can-INSTR cook-SUBIS-SEQ-EVR person-ACC-ADD eat-URGT-PST | \glt They [the Shining Path] even \textbf{cooked} people in metal pots and ate them, \textbf{they say}.

Knowledge Point: It is used systematically in stories~(\ref{Glo6:Unay}), (\ref{Glo6:Chaypaqshi}).
Content 1: \gsrc Unay\textbf{shi} kara huk asnu. | \gll unay-shi ka-ra huk asnu | \gls before-EVR be-PST one donkey | \glt \textbf{Once upon a time, they say} there was a mule.
Content 2: \gsrc Chaypaq\textbf{shi} kutirun maman kaqta papanin kaqta. | \gll chay-paq-shi kuti-ru-n mama-n ka-q-ta papa-ni-n ka-q-ta | \gls DEM.D-ABL-EVR return-URGT-3 mother-3 be-AG-ACC father-EUPH-3 be-AG-ACC | \glt He returned \textbf{from there, they say}, to his mother’s place, to his father’s place.

Knowledge Point: \phono{-trI}\index[sub]{evidentials!conjectural} indicates that the speaker does not have evidence for the proposition directly under the scope of the evidential, but is, rather, conjecturing to that proposition from others for which she does have evidence~(\ref{Glo6:Awayan}--\ref{Glo6:hamuyan}).
Content 1: \gsrc Awayan\textbf{tr}iki kamata. | \gll awa-ya-n-tr-iki kama-ta | \gls weave-PROG-EVR-IKI blanket-ACC | \glt \textbf{He must be weaving} a blanket.
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: \SYQ{} counts four evidential modifiers\index[sub]{evidentials!modification}, \phono{-ari} and the set \uo, \phono{-ik} and \phono{-iki}. \sectref{par:assertive} and~\ref{par:evistre} cover \phono{-ari} and \phono{-\uo/-ik/iki}, respectively. The latter largely repeats~\citet{Shimelman12}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: \phono{-aRi}\index[sub]{evidentials!assertive force} --~realized \phono{-ali} in \CH{}~(\ref{Glo6:Wayrakuyan}) and \phono{-ari} in all other dialects~-- indicates conviction on the part of the speaker.\footnote{The Quechuas of (at least) \ili{Ancash}-Huailas \citet[151]{Parker76gram},\index[aut]{Parker, Gary J.} \ili{Cajamarca}-Canaris \citet[158]{Quesada76}\index[aut]{Quesada Castillo, Félix} and Junin-\ili{Huanca} \citet[238--9]{CerroP76a}\index[aut]{Cerrón-Palomino, Rodolfo M.} have suffixes \phono{-rI}, \phono{-rI} and \phono{-ari}, respectively, which, like the \SYQ{} \phono{-k} succeed evidentials and are most often translated \spanish{pues} ‘then’. It seems unlikely that the \lsc{ahq}, \lsc{ccq} and \lsc{jhq} forms correspond to the \phono{-k} or \phono{-ki} of \SYQ. First, unlike \phono{-ik} or \phono{-iki}, \phono{-rI} and \phono{-ari} may appear independent of any evidential and they may function as general emphatics. Second, \SYQ, too, has a suffix \phono{-ari} which, like \phono{-rI} and \phono{-ari}, functions as a general emphatic, also translating as \spanish{pues}. Third, the \SYQ{} \phono{-ari} is in complementary distribution with \phono{-k} and \phono{-ki}. Finally, unlike the \lsc{ahq}, \lsc{ccq} and \lsc{jhq} forms, the \SYQ{} \phono{-ari} cannot appear independently of the evidentials \phono{-mI} or \phono{-shI} or else of \phono{-y}, and, further, always forms an independent word with these.}
Content 1: \gsrc Wayrakuyan\textbf{mari}. | \gll wayra-ku-ya-n-m-ari | \gls wind-REFL-PROG-3-EVD-ARI | \glt \textbf{It’s windy}.

Knowledge Point: It can often be translated as ‘surely’ or ‘certainly’ or ‘of course’. \phono{-aRi} generally occurs only in combination with \phono{-mI}~(\ref{Glo6:llapa}), (\ref{Glo6:firmachiwan}), \phono{-shI}~(\ref{Glo6:shali}), (\ref{Glo6:shari}) and \phono{-Yá}~(\ref{Glo6:Qillakuyanki}--\ref{Glo6:Yatraqninqa}).
Content 1: \gsrc Mana\textbf{mari} llapa ruwayaqhina kayani. | \gll mana-m-ari llapa ruwa-ya-q-hina ka-ya-ni | \gls no-EVD-ARI all make-PROG-AG-COMP be-PROG-1 | \glt \textbf{No, of course}, it seems like I’m making it all up.
Content 2: \gsrc Ñuqa[ta]s firmachiwan\textbf{mari}. Piru mana\textbf{shari} chay wawi warmiytapis firmachinraqchu. | \gll ñuqa[-ta]-s firma-chi-wa-n-m-ari piru mana-sh-ari chay wawi warmi-y-ta-pis firma-chi-n-raq-chu | \gls I-ACC-ADD sign-CAUS-1.OBJ-3-EVD-ARI but no-EVR-ARI DEM.D baby woman-1-ACC-ADD sign-CAUS-3-CONT-NEG | \glt \textbf{They made me sign}, too. But they \textbf{didn’t} make my daughter sign yet, \textbf{they say}.
Content 4: \gsrc Ripun\textbf{shari} umaqa kunkanman. | \gll ripu-n-sh-ari uma-qa kunka-n-man | \gls go-3-EVR-ARI head-TOP neck-3-ALL | \glt The head \textbf{went} [flying back] towards his neck, \textbf{they say}.
Content 5: \gsrc ¡Kurriy! Qillakuyanki\textbf{trari}. | \gll kurri-y qilla-ku-ya-nki-tr-ari | \gls run-IMP lazy-REFL-PROG-2-EVC-ARI | \glt Run!~\dots{} \textbf{You must be being lazy}.
Content 6: \gsrc Yatraqninqa mana yatraqninqa mana\textbf{yari}. | \gll yatra-q-ni-n-qa mana yatra-q-ni-n-qa mana-y-ari | \gls know-AG-EUPH-3-TOP no know-AG-EUPH-3-TOP no-EMPH-ARI | \glt The ones who knew how. The ones who didn’t know how, \textbf{no, of course}.

Knowledge Point: It is far less often employed than \phono{-ik} and \phono{-iki.} It is, however, prevalent in the LT dialect\phono, which supplied the single instance of \phono{tr-ari} in the corpus~(\ref{Glo6:itana}).
Content 1: \gsrc Chay wayra itana piru rimidyum Hilda. ¡Piru wachikun\textbf{yari}! | \gll chay wayra itana piru rimidyu-m Hilda piru wachi-ku-n-y-ari | \gls DEM.D wind thorn but remedy-EVD Hilda but sting-REFL-3-EMPH-ARI | \glt The wind thorns are medicinal, Hilda. But \textbf{do they ever sting}!

Knowledge Point: \SYQ{} is unusual\footnote{\ili{Ayacucho} Q also makes use of \phono{-ki}.} in that each of its three evidentials counts three variants, formed by the suffixation of \phono{-\uo}, \phono{-ik} or \phono{-iki}. The resulting nine forms are direct \phono{-mI-\uo}, \phono{-m-ik} and\phono{-m-iki}~(\ref{Glo6:trayamunchu}--\ref{Glo6:Wanuchinakun}); reportative \phono{-shI-\uo}, \phono{-sh-ik} and \phono{-sh-iki}~(\ref{Glo6:susyukuna}--\ref{Glo6:nisha}); and conjectural \phono{-trI-\uo}, \phono{-tr-ik} and\phono{-tr-iki}~(\ref{Glo6:Imapaqraq}--\ref{Glo6:Alkansachin}).\footnote{In Lincha, \phono{-iki} may modify both \phono{-mI} and \phono{-shI} but not \phono{-trI}; in Tana, \phono{-iki} may modify all three evidentials.}
Content 1: \gsrc Manam trayamunchu mana\textbf{mik} rikarinchu. | \gll mana-m traya-mu-n-chu mana-m-ik rikari-n-chu | \gls no-EVD arrive-CISL-3-NEG no-EVD-IK appear-3-NEG | \glt He \textbf{hasn’t} arrived. He \textbf{hasn’t} showed up.
Content 2: \gsrc Wañuchinakun ima\textbf{miki} chaytaqa muna:chu. | \gll wañu-chi-naku-n ima-m-iki chay-ta-qa muna-:-chu | \gls die-CAUS-RECIP-3 what-EVD-IKI DEM.D-ACC-TOP want-1-NEG | \glt They kill each other and \textbf{what-not, then}. I don’t want that.
Content 3: \gsrc Chay\textbf{shik} chay susyukuna ruwapakurqa chay nichuchanta wañushpa chayman pampakunanpaq. | \gll chay-sh-ik chay susyu-kuna ruwa-paku-rqa chay nichu-cha-n-ta wañu-shpa chay-man pampa-ku-na-n-paq | \gls DEM.D-EVR-IK DEM.D associates-PL make-JTACC-PST DEM.D crypt-DIM-3-ACC die-SUBIS DEM.D-ALL bury-REFL-NMLZ-3-PURP | \glt \textbf{That’s why, they say}, before, the members made each other the small crypts, to bury them when they died.
Content 4: \gsrc “¡Mátalo!” nisha\textbf{shiki}. | \gll mátalo ni-sha-sh-iki | \gls {[Spanish] say-NPST-EVR-IKI | \glt “Kill him!” \textbf{she’s said, they say}.
Content 5: \gsrc ¿Imapaqraq chayta ruwara paytaqa? Yanqaña\textbf{trik} chayta wañuchira. | \gll ima-paq-raq chay-ta ruwa-ra pay-ta-qa yanqa-ña-tr-ik chay-ta wañu-chi-ra | \gls what-PURP-CONT DEM.D-ACC make-PST he-ACC-TOP lie-DISC-EVC-IK DEM.D-ACC die-CAUS-PST | \glt What did they do that to him for? They \textbf{must have} killed him \textbf{just for the sake of it}.
Content 6: \gsrc Alkansachin warkawan\textbf{tri}. Kabrapis kasusam, piru. Riqsiyan\textbf{triki} runantaqa. | \gll alkansa-chi-n warka-wan-tri kabra-pis kasu-sa-m piru riqsi-ya-n-tr-iki runa-n-ta-qa | \gls reach-CAUS-3 sling-INSTR-EVC goat-ADD attention-PRF-EVD but know-PROG-3-EVC-IKI person-3-ACC-TOP | \glt She \textbf{must make [the stones] reach} with the sling, \textbf{for sure}. The goats obey her. They \textbf{must know} their master, \textbf{for sure}.

Knowledge Point: In questions, the evidentials\index[sub]{evidentials!questions} generally indicate that the speaker expects a response with the same evidential (\ie,~an answer based on direct evidence, reportative evidence or conjecture, in the cases of \phono{-mI}, \phono{-shI}, and \phono{-trI}, respectively)~(\ref{Glo6:Amador}--\ref{Glo6:Kutiramunman}).
Content 1: \gsrc ¿Amador Garaychu? ¿\textbf{Imam} sutin kara? | \gll Amador Garay-chu ima-m suti-n ka-ra | \gls Amador Garay-Q what-EVD name-3 be-PST | \glt Amador Garay? \textbf{What} was his name?
Content 2: \gsrc ¿Kutiramunman\textbf{chutr}? ¿\textbf{Imatrik} pasan? | \gll kuti-ra-mu-n-man-chu-tr ima-tr-ik pasan | \gls return-URGT-CISL-Q-EVC what-EVC-IK pass-3 | \glt \textbf{Could} he come back? \textbf{What would have} happened?

Knowledge Point: The use of \phono{-trI} in a question may, additionally, indicate that the speaker doesn’t actually expect any response at all~(\ref{Glo6:Kawsan}), while the use of \phono{-shI} may indicate not that the speaker is expecting an answer based on reported evidence, but that the speaker is reporting the question.
